reasoning: The critique targets a genuinely relevant support for the paper’s “fussy/narrow target” conclusion—namely, the move in the linear/unbounded discussion from fat-tailed value-efficiency to “must be aimed at a very specific configuration.” If that move failed, it would weaken one important route to fussiness, but it would not collapse the broader position, which also relies on multi-factor fragility (Section 2) and bounded-view arguments; hence moderate centrality. Strength is limited: the paper’s ‘best feasible future’ notion can already include robustness/longevity as part of what makes a configuration value-efficient, so pointing out that naive hyper-optimization Goodharts doesn’t show the target is broad or easy—optimal robust designs could still be narrow and hard to hit. The argument also assumes without support that slack reliably increases long-run expected value enough to overturn the ranking. Still, the core point (optimization can induce fragility; robustness can dominate snapshot efficiency) is often correct in analogous domains, so correctness is moderate. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Slack-filled suboptimal futures may outperform fragile optimized ones over time
